page.title: 04Lound and its Future
page.content: Lound was described in the Domesday Book as a hamlet. Its Viking name Lundr means "a grove in a plain". Although surrounded by farms Lound is no longer a farming village. The census returns, 1951, show 266 adults, half working on land and living in rented homes. With mechanisation farmers managed with less help, this meant that younger villagers left to find work. In 1970 the school, built in 1858, closed causing concern. 70 pupils attended but only 27 remained on roll. As more cottages became derelict, Lord Somerleyton,the main landlord,began to sell them. With growth of Lowestoft and Yarmouth, "outsiders" were attracted to Lound. Estate Agents regard Lound cottages as "desirable" homes. The newcomers mean Lound is fully occupied with neat homes in good repair. Lound's future seems secure.
